Award.AwardTitle: IDR: Self-Assembling Nanophotonic and Nanoelectronic Devices on DNA Nanobreadboards

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract

The objective of this research is to develop a novel self-assembly technique for fabricating nanoscale photonic and electronic devices. The approach is to use a single strand DNA designed to be self-assembled into a two-dimensional ?nanobreadboard? where nanoparticles such as quantum dots and metal nanoparticles are positioned precisely within a few nanometers of each other.

Intellectual Merit: In this project, a number of nanoscale devices such as a beamsplitter, modulator, and photodiode, with varying degree of synthesis complexity will be investigated. These devices will be designed with the computational program recently developed by the PIs. The project will address three research objectives: 1) design staple DNA strands and synthesize two-dimensional DNA nanobreadboard suitable for device assembly, 2) study the binding of functionalized nanoparticles on DNA nanobreadboard, and 3) experimentally characterize optical and electric properties of proposed devices using spectroscopy, time-of-flight, and pulsed I-V measurements.

Broader Impact: A major educational focus will be on graduate and undergraduate students in an interdisciplinary field. Research results will be incorporated into the Nanoscience/Nanotechnology courses recently developed, catering to the local industry?s need for engineers with a broader knowledge in nanotechnology and materials science. Underrepresented and underutilized groups will be recruited to the project. Students will present at annual outreach events ? Boise State Day at the State Legislature and NanoDays at the Discovery Center of Idaho. The research will have a transformative impact on the field of nanoscale integrated devices. It lays the foundation for new device technologies beyond those that have matured.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NSF IDR project develops a novel self-assembly technique for fabricating nanoscale photonic and electronic devices. Over the last decade, it has become clear that the cost of super high resolution lithography limits experimental exploration of the nanophotonic device. Manufacturing devices that interact with visible light in a controllable fashion becomes increasingly challenging. In this project, Devices are synthesized using 1D and 2D DNA origami nanobreadboards where nanoparticles such as dye molecules, quantum dots, and metal nanoparticles are arranged precisely within several nanometers from one another.

The project demonstrated functional and rationally designed nanoscale optical devices using DNA origami as a template. We investigated several nanophotonic devices: (1) plasmonic waveguide with Au nanoparticles arranged in linear chain; (2) plasmonic polarization rotator with Au nanoparticles arranged in helical shapes; and (3) dynamic optical nanostructure, where the optical properties can be modified via external stimuli. We investigated reconfigurable DNA nanobreadboards for modular assembly of near-field optoelectronic devices and to arrange dye molecules onto nanobreadboards to fabricate specific near-field logic gate optoelectronic devices to spectrally perform dynamic logic operations via Förster resonance energy transfer. The project demonstrated that self-assembled nanostructure can possess long-range ordering via specific binding, which is an important milestone for self-assembly technique to be adopted for optical devices and materials fabrication.

In carrying out the experiment work, the project developed a number of resources that could be useful for others in the science and engineering communities. (1) We developed an automatic beam stabilization and alignment system. The system utilizes 2 independent piezo actuated motorized mirror mounts with active 4-axis control to achieve excellent passive stability. For visible and near infrared wavelength, the system uses 2 miniature position-sensing cameras to provide continuous tracking of laser beam positions. (2) We developed a motorized polarizer plate for Nikon Ti-U microscope. The plate is designed to fit into the microscope adapter slot and provide a continuous 360° rotation of linear polarization at a resolution of 0.5°. The polarizer plate is in the common beam path to the eyepiece and auxiliary optical ports.

This research also contributed to human resources development in a number of ways. It has provided opportunities for research and training for undergraduate and graduate students. Particularly for undergraduate students, the opportunity to work in a research laboratory and interactions with graduate students provide valuable mentoring experiences. A number of students involved in this project were awarded during the period of this project. Finally, the investigators and students participated annually in outreach activities including: (1) lab tours yearly to the perspective students, Idaho Science & Aerospace Scholars, the Idaho State Board of Education, Western Legislative Fiscal Officers, and Directors of Micron Technology; (2) STEM Discovery Day at Boise State University annually. STEM Discovery Day is a free event for children and families with a wide variety of engaging activities designed for preschool through high school ages. These outreach activities expose the local community to the DNA nanotechnology research at Boise State University and increase the public awareness and participation of science and technology.
